**The Red Pine Master’s Petition Rituals**

*Scripture Title:* *The Red Pine Master’s Petition Rituals*. Author unknown; according to scholarly consensus, compiled by Tang-dynasty Daoist priests. A manual of early Celestial Master Daoist petition rituals. Six juan in total. Base text from the *Zhengtong Daoist Canon*, *Dongxuan* section, *Petition Memorials* category.

**The Red Pine Master’s Petition Rituals, Juan One**

Respectfully following *The Supreme Perfection Regulations* and *The Red Pine Master’s Records*: In the Han dynasty, humans and spirits intermingled, and malevolent forces spread unchecked. The Most High, moved by compassion, descended upon Mount Heming and bestowed upon Heavenly Master Zhang the *Orthodox Unity Alliance Registers* of one hundred twenty ranks, along with one thousand two hundred official protocols, three hundred major petitions, and esoteric ritual texts—all to succor and heal the living.

The Heavenly Master then established twenty-four dioceses, disseminating the *Orthodox Unity* petitions and talismans, registering households, and transforming the people while widely practicing hidden virtue. Yet as the ages passed, the precious petitions were lost, and what remains today is but one or two parts in ten.

Further, according to the record: Red Pine Master asked Heavenly Elder Pingchang, “Why has the petition submitted on the *jichou* day gone unreported?” Pingchang replied, “I saw the petition-bearer arrive at the Heavenly Gate, but the gate was closed.” The Master asked again, “When does it open and close in the span of a day and night?” Pingchang answered in full, precisely as the ritual codes prescribe.

Moreover, when people submit petitions, their purposes vary—some for the state and household, others for themselves, their kin, or deceased ancestors. Each case differs and must be distinguished accordingly.

It is also said: The lifespan and fate of every person are governed by stellar constellations. If one commits evil deeds, their name is recorded in the Black Register, causing their spirit to grow restless, their dreams troubled, their path beset by misfortune, and their years diminished. But for those of pure heart who revere the Dao and its methods, seeking petitions and talismans, their transgressions are erased, blessings arise, their emoluments and longevity increase, their ancestors ascend, and their wishes are fulfilled.

All petitions must first be accompanied by offerings, so that the divine luminaries may witness one’s sincerity. Without offerings, the gods will not accept them, and one will be rebuked for stinginess and reluctance to give.

It is further said: The offerings for petitions are not fixed—those of wealth may increase them, while the poor may reduce them. Yet even among high officials and affluent households, if they covet merit but begrudge their wealth, mimicking the poor in their offerings, such conduct will yield no benefit.

The codes state: For those who are destitute and impoverished, seeking petitions and jiao rituals, the master may provide the ritual offerings on their behalf.

Though old petitions vary in purpose, they generally fall into three categories: those for the Son of Heaven, for nobles and high officials, and for commoners. Since ranks differ, their forms must not be conflated without distinction.

The codes also state: Offerings for petitions should be distributed to the poor to cultivate hidden virtue; the master must not use them entirely for himself. Calculating by tenths, the master may only take three parts for his own use. The celestial statutes are severe—those who violate them incur punishment from the Three Officials, their misfortune extending to nine generations, condemning them to eternal servitude as lowly spirits. How could one not be cautious!

Now, these matters are arranged and compared, with clear principles established, so that practitioners may know the proper order.

**Three Grades of Petitions**
One thousand two hundred official rituals, three hundred major petitions. Though each petition includes its own offerings, the teachings have been transmitted for a long time, and practitioners often make additions or omissions. Thus, ranks become indistinguishable, and distinctions unclear. Here, three grades are extracted as a standard.

**Silk and Colors:**
The Son of Heaven uses purple silk in *pi* and *shu* quantities; princes and dukes use their life-color silk in *zhang* quantities; commoners use plain silk in *chi* quantities.

**Ritual Coins:**
The Son of Heaven uses gold coins; princes and dukes use silver coins; commoners use copper coins.

**Rice Offerings:**
The Son of Heaven offers three *shi* and six *dou*; princes and dukes offer two *shi* and four *dou*; commoners offer one *shi* and two *dou*.

**Ritual Oil:**
The Son of Heaven offers one *shi* and two *dou*; princes and dukes offer six *dou* and four *sheng*; commoners offer two *dou* and two *sheng*.

**Incense:**
The Son of Heaven offers a full *jin*; princes and dukes offer half a *jin*; commoners offer three or five *liang*.

**Paper, Brushes, Ink, and Cinnabar:**
These are provided for the officiant to draft petitions, correct errors, and revise drafts. All petitions must include them; none may be omitted. Other items follow their original categories and quantities. Violations will result in a reduction of lifespan.

**Petition Texts**
When submitting a petition, first prepare a written statement listing one’s native place, village name, official title, full name, age, household members, living dependents, and the number of males and females, young and old. According to Daoist regulations, present the ritual offerings at a designated place to a designated master, requesting the submission of the petition. Humbly beseech compassion and special intervention. The statement should convey the matter plainly, without ornamentation—unrefined yet not crude, simple yet not ostentatious, truthful yet not deceitful, direct yet not unrestrained, articulate yet not verbose, modest yet not vulgar, pure yet not turbid. If sincerity is concise and earnest, it will move Heaven and Earth, stir spirits and gods, ascend to the celestial bureaus, and bring swift retribution. Violations will result in the forfeiture of twelve years of lifespan.

**Five Tones for Presenting Petitions and Their Uses**
- **Establishment Day:** Nine petitions may be presented. Suitable for promoting the Great Dao and eliminating inauspicious *qi*, ghosts, and bandits. Do not use for cursing ancestral temples—this harms the household and the master. Avoid the *shen* hour, when the Dipper strikes downward. *(Other days follow this pattern.)*
- **Removal Day:** Twelve petitions may be presented. Suitable for treating illness and resolving ancestral tomb afflictions affecting descendants. Do not use for protecting wealth. Avoid the *you* hour.
- **Full Day:** Six petitions may be presented. Suitable for securing ancestral tombs and protecting wealth. Do not use for resolving household depletion—this harms livestock. Avoid the *xu* hour.
- **Level Day:** Seventeen petitions may be presented. Suitable for resolving taboos and eliminating various evils. Do not use for protecting wealth or livestock—this harms the master and servants. Avoid the *hai* hour.
- **Stabilization Day:** Seventeen petitions may be presented. Suitable for five-directional protection, securing the residence, and resolving high officials’ depletion. Do not use for removing old *qi*—this harms elders. Avoid the *zi* hour.
- **Execution Day:** Five petitions may be presented. Suitable for capturing ghosts and bandits and resolving imprisonment. Do not use for treating illness—this harms the sick.

Avoid the *chou* hour.
- **Destruction Day:** Seven petitions may be presented. Suitable for executing ancestral temple rites, eliminating calamitous spirits, and suppressing malevolent deaths. Do not use for resolving tomb desecration or lineage extinction—this is inauspicious. Avoid the *yin* hour.
- **Peril Day:** Twelve petitions may be presented. Suitable for stellar deliverance, resolving the dead’s retribution upon descendants, and breaking ancestral entanglements. Do not use for securing the residence—this harms livestock. Avoid the *mao* hour.
- **Completion Day:** Eighteen petitions may be presented. Suitable for official appointments, protecting all household members, and treating illness. Do not use for distant travel—travelers will not return. Avoid the *chen* hour.
- **Reception Day:** One hundred twenty petitions may be presented. Suitable for repenting transgressions, averting misfortune, protecting livestock, and securing the residence. Do not use for resolving official matters—this leads to imprisonment and death. Avoid the *si* hour.
- **Inauguration Day:** One hundred twenty petitions may be presented. Suitable for removing old *qi* from ancestral temples, subduing myriad sorcerers, expelling livestock spirits, and eliminating household demons. Do not use for resolving the dead’s retribution—this kills livestock. Avoid the *wu* hour.
- **Closure Day:** Five petitions may be presented. Suitable for resolving earthwork taboos and breaking baleful influences on fate. Do not use for protecting household members—this harms property. Avoid the *wei* hour.

**Method for Writing Talismans**
When intending to write a talisman, first face the *wang* direction, knock the teeth, command the sword-water, visualize the Seven Stars, recite the incantation, and spray the water. Then declare:

*"Primordial Life True Person, Generals Tang, Ge, and Zhou, there is now a man or woman named so-and-so suffering from illness, who petitions me for aid and protection. I reverently follow the Daoist method, bestowing upon so-and-so this true talisman of the Dao to swallow or wear. May the true officials, direct talisman messengers, and the hundred thousand myriad layers of Dao qi descend into this talisman by command. Let the spirits mobilize the qi, search out and expel evil spirits, execute demonic thieves, and deliver salvation to the celestial and human realms."*

Next, visualize the five-colored true qi before the altar. Above the true qi, to the left and right, stand the Direct Talisman Lads, clad in vermilion robes and azure skirts. Before the altar stands a Talisman General in vermilion robes and a dark crown, girded with a sword and holding a battle-axe. To his left and right stand two Direct Talisman Attendants, wearing yellow caps, yellow skirts, and crimson-brown garments, each holding a sword. Before me are the sun on the left and the moon on the right, nine inches from my face, their radiance covering a vermilion vessel. Above my head are the Seven Stars, the stars upon my head, and the *piao* upon the vermilion vessel.

Once this is complete, recite thrice: *"Conjoined Brightness of the Heavenly Thearch and the Sun."*

Then, visualize the vermilion brush as a *tengshe*, hold the breath, and write the talisman.

**General Method for Writing Talismans**
First, outline the four sides of the talisman with azure ink, then write the talisman text within in cinnabar. If azure ink is unavailable, cinnabar may also be used.

When writing talismans to cure illnesses caused by evil, use true cinnabar mixed with tiger bone. Once ground, dip the brush and write the talisman while reciting the incantation:

*"I solemnly command the true officials within my five bodily constituents: my hun-soul is the Heavenly Father, my po-soul is the Earthly Mother, my head is Lord Thunder, my hair is black clouds, my crown is the Bright Star, my forehead is the Vermilion Bird, my eyebrows are the Qilin, my eyes are the sun and moon, my nose is the Mighty Tiger, my upper lip is the Earl of Wind, my lower lip is the Master of Rain, my tongue is the Governor of the Nine Provinces, my throat is the Nine-Layered Tower, my left cheek is the Eastern Kingly Lord, my right cheek is the Queen Mother of the West, my ears are the Immortal Lads of Distant Hearing, my neck is the Heavenly Pillar, my shoulders are the Vajras, my elbows are the Mighty Warriors, my left arm is the Great General Xuanji of Expelling Barbarians, my right arm is the Great General Yuheng of Breaking Barbarians, my palms are fire chariots, my fingers are armored soldiers, my liver is the Green Thearch, my lungs are the White Thearch, my heart is the Red Thearch, my kidneys are the Black Thearch, my spleen is the Yellow Thearch, my intestines are the Yellow Dragon, my gallbladder is the Great One, my bladder is the River Earl, my blood is the Water Official, my sinews are the Heavenly Net, my bones are the Earthly Net, my hair is the Heavenly Snare, my feet are the White Horse, my forward steps are the Three Officials, each leading seventy million troops. Mounting great chariots, they emerge from within my body to assist me in writing the talisman and mobilizing the qi, destroying and executing malevolent demons, *wangliang*, *chimei*, evil ghosts, and perverse qi. Swiftly, swiftly, in accordance with the oral command of the Most High!"*

For the *jiazi*旬, the Illness-Curing Messenger commands the Black Merit Clerk; at the *zi* hour, the Most High returns to govern.

**Method for Writing Memorials**
When writing memorials, do not mix brushes and inkstones. Grind the ink by rotating the inkstick leftward forty-nine times; the grinding stone should be treated likewise. The heading "With respectful hearing" should be placed one inch below the first bow. The supplicant’s surname should be placed three lines below "With respectful hearing." "Great Clarity" should be placed three lines below the supplicant’s surname. "Great Year" should be placed three lines below "Great Clarity."

If a memorial is completed but contains minor matters, it may not be submitted for a year. If small characters have not yet been added, it may be submitted within a month. For small characters: the upper measure is three inches and five *fen*, the middle measure four inches and five *fen*, and the lower measure five inches—no more than this. Many today speak of one inch and five *fen*, which is incorrect. When the memorial reaches "Great Year," if the paper is exhausted, it may not be submitted. If there is a presiding officer to deliver it, then it may. If two lines remain, the paper may be fully extended to continue.

For errors or omitted characters: small memorials should not exceed three characters; large memorials should be judged by context. When writing memorials, leave eight *fen* of space at the top and allow the bottom to extend to the edge of the paper. Place a cloth on the desk when writing memorials; do not let them touch the bed. Do not place clothing on the memorial or let it fall to the ground.

When writing memorials, enter a state of stillness. Do not allow ordinary people to cause disturbance, nor discuss other matters or speak of foul or defiling things. When writing memorials, do not dip the brush in water or in the mouth. Keep the mouth closed, do not eat anything, and avoid exhaling forcefully. Wash hands clean and face north when writing. If the body has been defiled, do not write memorials. Do not write incomplete or flawed characters, nor use torn or damaged paper. Do not drink alcohol, eat meat, or expose oneself to foul odors. Dress in proper attire; do not expose the body.

When writing memorials, one must prostrate oneself in reverence; do not squat or sit casually. After completing a memorial, first proofread it once before submitting it. The character "Your servant" (*chen*) must not appear at the beginning of a line, nor should it be placed where the living and dead are juxtaposed. The character for "ghost" must not occupy the start of a line. Do not tear out or damage a person’s name, nor allow others to secretly read it, lest it disturb the Great Clarity. The characters for "sun" and "moon" should not be written in advance; they should be added at the time of submission.

If submitting an urgent memorial, use a vermilion brush for the heading. When submitting a memorial to expel ghosts, write in vermilion the name of the Orthodox Unity disciple submitting it. For memorials to cure illnesses caused by malevolent spirits, use blue paper. The Lords and Officers of the Three Officials hold blue in high esteem. For memorials to strike down ghostly illnesses caused by *zhu* qi, write in vermilion on blue paper.

After the memorial is submitted, burn it in the place of treatment. Grind two parts of true cinnabar and mix with honey to form pills. At dawn, enter the oratory, bow twice, and consume them—even those at death’s door will revive. Let no one know of this.

If writing a memorial due to illness while in the oratory, burn incense on all four sides.

**Invoking the Officials**
The *Tai Zhen* regulations decree: For all illnesses, first submit a *Shouzhuang* memorial. If recovery does not follow, submit a *Jiekao* memorial. If still unwell, submit a *Jie Xianwang Zuizhe* memorial. If the condition persists, submit a *Qianda* memorial. Should the illness deepen, submit a *Que Sha Shouzhu Guishen* memorial. If suddenly stricken, submit a *Jie Huo’e Dachang* memorial. If no improvement, submit a *Jie Wumu Zhe* memorial. If still unwell, submit a *Fushuai Duyue Dachang* memorial. If no recovery, submit a *Huanhun Fupo* memorial. If the condition endures, submit an *Anmu Jie Wutu Haohai* memorial. If still unwell, submit an *Anzhai Zhenshen Quchu Shougui* memorial. If no improvement, submit a *Fenjie Zhongwai Dako* memorial. In dire straits, submit a *Ziwu Qingming Bing Que Sanguan Sijie* memorial. If the condition fluctuates, submit a *Yangxie Sanshier Tian* memorial. In critical peril, submit the *Xuming Wencui*, *Baming*, *Dujie Fulian*, *Wudeng*, *Ershiba Xiu*, and *Fenjie Xianwang Dazhu Bashiyi* memorials. Should no such affliction exist, these memorials must not be recklessly invoked. Violators shall be subject to *Er Xing* punishment.

*Er Xing* entails sweeping roads and repairing bridges. *Wu Xing* punishment requires delivering three thousand bundles of thatch to the Heavenly Master for roof repairs. *Liu Xing* punishment demands supplying two thousand roof tiles. *Yi Xing* entails sweeping roads for twenty days; *Er Xing*, for twenty days. A *Ji* refers to one year; an *allotted span* denotes ten days, or sometimes one day per span. For grave matters, memorials may extend to three or four hundred characters; for those on the brink of death, five hundred characters. Minor matters should be limited to one or two hundred characters—excessive length disperses vital qi, causing officials and soldiers to fail in their duties.

For urgent memorials, invoke *Tian Chang Jun*, accompanied by one hundred thousand yellow-robed soldiers. Alternatively, enter the oratory, face east, and orally petition to summon one hundred twenty calamities and malevolent spirits from within and without, including the twelve *Xing Sha* ghosts. For afflictions of the face, submit a memorial and enter the oratory to invoke *Tian Ming Jun* and five attendants, with one hundred twenty officials stationed beneath the Southern Palace to treat facial ailments. For rebellious qi, vomiting, or diarrhea of the five epidemics, five poisons, six *liu*, or six ghosts, invoke *Beixing Daji Jun*, with one hundred twenty officials stationed beneath the Six Palaces to administer treatment. For distension in the right abdomen, cramping of the small intestine, *Daixia*, or the twelve disease-causing ghosts, invoke *Feng Li Jun*, with one hundred twenty officials to provide remedy. For undigested food, hardened accumulations, or unrelenting strangury, invoke *Chi Su Jun*, with one hundred twenty officials to administer treatment. For counterflow qi, acute pain, abdominal hardness, or inability to retain food, invoke *Wu Heng Jun*, with one hundred twenty officials stationed beneath the Great Mound Palace to provide remedy. For vomiting and counterflow, invoke *Wu Heng Jun*, with one hundred twenty officials stationed in the *Taiping* Palace. For distension in the lower abdomen, invoke *Jiuhe Beihai Jun*, with one hundred twenty officials stationed in the *Heyuan* Palace. For illnesses caused by well or stove ghosts, invoke *Wang Fa Jun* and five attendants, with one hundred twenty officials stationed in the Five Surnames Palace to suppress and eradicate them. For carbuncles and abscesses, invoke *Jiu Ji Jun*, with one hundred twenty officials stationed in the Western Jade Palace to administer treatment. For emaciation, bone dissolution, and extreme exhaustion, invoke *Yang Zhi Jun*, with one hundred twenty officials on each side to provide remedy. To prolong life, invoke *Nan Shang Jun*, with one hundred twenty officials stationed in the *Cangguo* Palace to bestow longevity and immortality. For chronic bedridden suffering, invoke *Xu Yi Jun*, with one hundred twenty officials to administer treatment. To suppress malevolent spirits within the household, invoke *Shi Xian Jun* and one attendant, with one hundred twenty officials to subdue them. To expel old qi, sever ghostly afflictions, avert death, and invite rebirth, or to transform misfortune into fortune, invoke *Yi Tian Jiangjun* with one hundred thousand soldiers to capture and eradicate them. To subdue the essences of ancient spirits invading the household, invoke *Shangyuan Shijun* and one attendant, with one hundred twenty officials to apprehend them. For violations of one’s *Xingnian Benming*, *Taisui* earth, Five Graves, or *Chen Jian Po*, invoke *Zhi Di Jun* and five attendants, with one hundred twenty officials to descend to their palace and eradicate them. For inauspicious qi or litigious ghosts causing household unrest, invoke *Hu Jun*, with one hundred twenty officials to dissolve and sever them. For frequent deaths or personal afflictions of punishment and harm, invoke *Yunqi Jie’e Jun*, with seven hundred thousand soldiers to administer treatment. For disturbances by Five Graves ghosts or wandering harming spirits, invoke *Wushang Gaocang Jun*, with seven hundred thousand soldiers to capture and eradicate them. For recurrent household fires, invoke *Wushang Tian Jun*, with one hundred thousand soldiers to sever them. To break ancestral temple curses or expel demonic objects, invoke *Ping Tian Jun*, with one hundred twenty officials stationed in the Northern *Shuo* Palace to administer treatment. To pursue immortality while plagued by lingering illnesses, invoke *Xusu Tianjing Jun*, with one hundred thousand red-robed soldiers stationed in the *Tianzhu* Palace to suppress ghosts, eradicate misfortune, and repel the qi of the Red Heaven.

If the household harbors malevolent ghosts that refuse to disperse and persist in their mischief, invoke *Chi Tian Shi Qi Jun*, with one hundred twenty officials to administer treatment. If the household suffers from unease in the *kan* trigram, disordered dreams, or unanchored hun and po souls, invoke *Shoushen Shangyu Jun*, with one hundred twenty officials to govern and heal.

The officials invoked to treat illnesses correspond to the twenty-four spirits residing within the body. The numbers of officials, generals, scribes, and soldiers all arise from the Daoist Three *Qi* in response to circumstances—these are not beings born of Heaven and Earth. When sincerity is expressed, resonance is achieved through things, and thus *qi* takes form to become scribes and soldiers.

The remaining official titles are recorded in the *One Thousand Two Hundred Official Rites*. These twenty-four principal titles correspond to the twenty-four spirits within the body. In times of urgency, invoke them according to the matter at hand; all will prove efficacious. Alternatively, one may enter the oratory, burn incense, and orally petition the four directions to seek deliverance.

**Method for Sealing Memorials**

Once the memorial is read, place it on the memorial table and secure it with a vermilion brush and a ritual knife. After the recitation is complete, roll it tightly according to protocol, pass it through incense smoke, and seal it with a whole sheet of paper. The address shall read:

*Most reverently presented to the Jade Sovereign of the Golden Portal of Spontaneous Emptiness.*

Below, state the rank of the petitioner:

*Tai Xuan Du Zhengyi Ping Qi, affiliated with Celestial Master Yangping District, Left Ping Qi Gate, holding the rank of Third-Grade Grand Capital Merit, concurrently Left Censor and Libationer, Chi Tian Sanwu Bugang Yuanming Zhenren, your subject [Name], respectfully seals this memorial.*

Next, place the memorial in its case, bind it with three strands of green silk, and fill the seal’s impression well with wax. Affix the seal of the *Nine Elder Immortals’ Capital*. Then, enclose it in an outer wrapping of green paper. First, mark it with vermilion dots—ensure the top and bottom are not inverted. Then seal both ends, inscribing a complete character. Write in vermilion and impress each with the seal.

The outer wrapper shall be addressed as follows:

*Respectfully submitted on behalf of the disciple of the Great Dao, [Official Title and Name], for the matter of [specific purpose], presenting [number] memorials, most humbly delivered to the Gate of the Three Heavens for transmission.*

The characters *Gate of the Three Heavens* must be written level. The characters *for transmission* shall be inscribed to the side of *Gate of the Three Heavens*. Below, state the petitioner’s rank as before: *[Name] respectfully seals this memorial.* Impress the seal over the *respectfully seals* inscription. *Defilement and impurity.*

**Regulations on Defilement and Impurity**

The statutes prescribe: When a household experiences a death, regardless of age, or when a woman gives birth, the defilement for a major funeral shall last one hundred days. For childbirth, as it harms the woman’s body, the defilement shall also last one hundred days. Entering the chamber of a woman in labor incurs three days of defilement. The death of a child or servant incurs one month of defilement. The death of livestock incurs one day of defilement. If the death occurs outside the household, there shall be no defilement. For a one-year mourning period, the defilement lasts forty days. For *da gong* and *si ma* mourning, defilement applies within the month; after the month has passed, it is lifted. Visiting a bereaved household to weep incurs defilement for that day. Prolonged mourning incurs no defilement. One must not partake of sacrificial food at a funeral, nor of food offered three days after childbirth or at the full-month celebration. None of the aforementioned defilements may engage in purification rites, set up *jiao* offerings, or present memorials. If encountered elsewhere, the defilement may be dispelled with talismanic water.

**Regulations on Visualization**

Upon completing the ritual recitations, prostrate before the altar and visualize a crimson *qi* emanating from your heart, ascending to the heavens. After a moment, as if traversing a hundred *li*, the path of crimson *qi* stretches boundlessly, unobstructed by blemish or shadow, lined only with jeweled trees. Suddenly, a yellow path appears—this is the Yellow Path of the Sun and Moon. After crossing five or six *li* beyond it, distant purple clouds loom faintly. Upon reaching the purple clouds, the Gate of Heaven comes into view. The gate spans one *zhang* and eight *chi*, and all attendants halt. Only the Perimeter General, the Direct Envoy, and the Merit Clerk may transmit the memorial. Jade lads bear the memorial to the threshold, where they present it to the west. There, the Orthodox Unity Three Heavens Master, surnamed Zhang and named Daoling, is seen. After bowing, the details of the memorial are fully recited. The Heavenly Master performs nine prostrations, then proceeds to the Phoenix Pavilion Gate to enter. Soon, a jade lad in vermilion robes and a dark cap emerges to receive the memorial. The jade lads take the memorial inside, and after a brief moment, reemerge to escort the petitioner before the Most High. The Most High wears a robe of nine-colored cloud radiance and a crown of ninefold virtue, seated upon the dais with the Two Mystic Perfected Ones attending to his left and right. The Great One, clad in vermilion robes and a dark cap, presents the memorial to the Most High. After a single glance, the Great One, following the Most High’s intent, inscribes "By the command of the Jade Emperor of the Great Clarity" and affixes the proper characters. The task complete, another jade lad collects the memorial from the right steps and entrusts it to the Duty Clerk of the day. The petitioner bows in reverence, takes leave of the Most High, and departs. Again, he bows to take leave of the Heavenly Master. Together with the memorial’s divine officials, he rejoices and returns to the place of presentation. Rising, he announces the completion of the ritual.

**Storing Memorials (Original Text of the *Tai Zhen Statutes*)**

After presenting a memorial on another’s behalf, once all minor memorials have been returned to the incense burner, roll them and place them in a case. Carry them out separately, then retrieve all major memorials at once, recording them as prescribed. If they are to be burned, do so before the incense burner. If transporting memorials from elsewhere, inscribe, seal, and secure them to prevent exposure to insects, rodents, or bartering for profit—violations contravene the Most High’s decrees. Memorials contain the titles of true officials, the names of spirits and deities, and secret numinous instructions; they must not be defiled. All memorials have original copies, which serve as clear references for verification. Never use old copies. As circumstances and petitions differ, so too do the celestial palaces addressed. Common households must not retain copies of memorials. Violations are punishable by the Five Punishments.

**The Heavenly Elder Questions the Three Sovereigns**
The Heavenly Elder questioned the Three Sovereigns: “Why are talismans made on *wuxu* days?”

The Three Sovereigns replied: “*Xu* is the Gate of Heaven. *Wu* is the likeness of the Earth’s Central Office and its Lord. The Heavenly Thearch customarily descends from the Gate of Heaven to wander on *wuxu* days. When talismans are crafted on this day, he rejoices and bestows the fulfillment of wishes. *Wu* pertains to earth; thus, one is certain to attain official rank, be enfeoffed as a marquis, and receive a domain.”

They are to be worn at the hour of *wu*, for *wu* embodies the essence of the Great Yang and the radiance of pure metal—an emblem of lofty rank and golden-purple eminence.

**Avoidances and Taboos**

**Regulations and Prohibitions**

The Regulations state: When submitting memorials or performing *jiao* rites, disciples must not take life. Violations reduce one’s allotted years by twenty-four.

When submitting memorials, all members of the household, including fowl and dogs, must not create clamor. Violations incur a penalty of twelve years’ reduction.

Memorials must not be submitted during great winds, heavy rains, or prolonged storms. Violations result in one year of illness.

Those afflicted with the six ailments must not submit memorials on behalf of others. Violations reduce one’s allotted years by thirty-six.

When submitting memorials, one must not consume wine, meat, or the five pungent vegetables. Violations reduce one’s allotted years by twelve.

**Prohibitions**

The Prohibitions state: When submitting memorials in the offices of the Dao to request official appointments, one must not transgress or err. Those defiled by impurity must not enter the ritual space.

Those who have witnessed a burial must not enter rivers, mountains, marshes, or forests. Livestock that have given birth within seven days must not enter the ritual space. Infants under one hundred days old must not enter the ritual space. Livestock that have borne young within a month must not enter the ritual space.

Objects of faith used in memorials and *jiao* rites must not be lent to others. Within the ritual space, one must not burn foul or odorous substances, nor feathers, hides, or horns.

All who enter the ritual space must do so with reverence and solemnity, performing rites of obeisance. One must not act with arrogance or irreverence.

Within the ritual space, one must not point or gesture, speak recklessly or unlawfully, or engage in frivolous speech or laughter. One must not expose the body.

Offerings of faith must be distributed among the Daoist faithful.

When approaching the ritual space to submit memorials for the salvation of the sick or the alleviation of misfortune, one must don a sash, wear wooden clogs, and bow respectfully, knocking one’s head to the ground while recounting the matter in full. One must not act with arrogance, cruelty, or haughtiness, nor raise one’s voice in self-aggrandizement. Violations are judged under the three penalties.

The Decrees state: If a father is afflicted with illness or misfortune while his son bears the great register of the Celestial Master, the father must don a cap and hempen robe, knock his head to the ground, and strike his cheeks. Only then may the son enter the ritual space to submit the memorial.

The Decrees state: If father and son seek to make requests improperly, both father and son are judged under the three penalties. The same applies to brothers.

The Decrees state: If a woman holds a register of the Dao and her husband faces urgent misfortune, he must don a sash, wear wooden clogs, and bow respectfully according to the rites. Only then may the woman enter the oratory to submit the memorial.

The Decrees state: If a husband makes a request improperly, he is judged under two penalties. If a wife fails to proclaim the decree clearly, she is judged under three penalties.

The Decrees state: If an uncle or elder male cousin is afflicted with illness or misfortune while a nephew or younger male cousin bears the register, the latter must submit a memorial as in the case of father and son.

The Decrees state: If a mother’s brother or sister is afflicted with illness or misfortune, and their children or grandchildren seek to submit a memorial, they must do so as in the case of uncles and nephews.

The Decrees state: Those who commit heinous acts—wielding the sword to execute, plotting against their lord, or murdering their father—are guilty of great treason. No amount of wealth or merit can atone for such crimes. They shall tread upon the Mountain of Knives, ascend the Forest of Swords, endure the cauldron’s boiling waters, and suffer burning and scalding for ten thousand generations without reprieve, their sins beyond redemption.

**Disciplinary Statutes**

The Disciplinary Statutes state: Within the human body resides a spirit that records transgressions, ascending and descending with the passing of time, daily noting good and evil.

One hundred and twenty transgressions form a *ke*, which brings more harm than benefit. One hundred and eighty transgressions form a *hao*, which causes livestock to fail to reproduce. Ten transgressions form a *bian*, which brings illness. Five hundred and forty transgressions form a *xiong*, which harms the fetus and injures children. Seven hundred and twenty transgressions form a *chui*, which brings death. Seven hundred and twenty-nine transgressions form a *yang*, which causes muteness, paralysis, blindness, or deafness. One thousand and eighty transgressions form a *huo*, which brings sudden, premature death. One thousand two hundred transgressions form a *can*, which produces rebellious offspring. One thousand two hundred and sixty transgressions form a *jiu*, which severs the line of descent. One thousand four hundred transgressions form a *ji*, which brings calamity flowing through five generations. One thousand six hundred and twenty transgressions form a *zhe*, which severs the lineage, leaving no descendants. One thousand eight hundred transgressions form a *huan*, which causes the family to produce those afflicted with madness or idiocy. Two thousand and sixty transgressions form a *bao*, which brings violent death by weapons. Two thousand three hundred and thirty transgressions form a *xu*, which causes family members—father and son, brothers—to attack one another. Two thousand five hundred and twenty transgressions form a *zeng*, which brings severe skin diseases to the family. Two thousand seven hundred transgressions form a *hai*, which causes deafness in the family. Two thousand eight hundred transgressions form a *zai*, which brings familial incest, depravity, and rebellion. Three thousand and sixty transgressions form a *yi*, which causes the family to produce the blind, the castrated, or the mutilated. Three thousand one hundred and thirty transgressions form a *bian*, which brings imprisonment, execution, or the extermination of the clan. Three thousand one hundred and fifty transgressions form a *guai*, which causes the family to produce beggars in the marketplace, their bones discarded and abandoned. Three thousand six hundred transgressions form a *man*, which necessitates death.

The Statutes state: Some die at twenty or thirty, their *ke* filled with misfortune and early death. Others reach fifty or sixty before their *ke* fills with misfortune and early death. Some, though having committed no transgressions in youth, die prematurely—these inherit the residual transgressions of past lives. Others, though committing great evil and treason, live out their years without encountering disaster—they inherit the residual blessings of their ancestors.

Thus, the accumulation of virtue leaves residual fortune, while the accumulation of evil leaves residual misfortune. If one can repent of transgressions, they vanish and fortune arises. One must reflect on one’s faults, take responsibility, reform, and never repeat them. Practicing this for ten days removes one *ke* of transgressions from the spirit within. Practicing for one hundred days removes two *ke*. Practicing for one year removes three *ke*. Practicing for three years brings the corresponding fortune.

If one does not reflect or repent, transgressions deepen daily. Minor transgressions harm only oneself; major transgressions flow down to descendants. Accumulated goodness is like dust upon a beam; accumulated evil is like smoke within a chimney. How can one not be vigilant?

**Memorial for Drought** (天旱章)

**Memorial for Drought**

We humbly submit: According to the sacred writ, we, Your servants, though foolish and unworthy, have encountered this Daoist congregation and been blessed to witness this sagely age. By fortunate coincidence, we have been touched by the Great Law. We prostrate ourselves in gratitude to the Most High, whose vast embrace and merciful compassion of the Master Lords have bestowed upon us grace without the slightest merit of our own. Day and night, we tremble with dread, as though treading upon ice or crossing a ravine, unable to repay even a fraction of the恩 of Heaven and Earth.

On the day we received the Law, we vowed to serve the Master’s gate with reverence, to disseminate virtue and power, to assist the state and sustain life, to deliver all beings, and to place salvation of the myriad creatures above all else. Yet of late, the cycles of Heaven and Earth have turned adverse; yin and yang clash; the four seasons lose their proper measure. The realm suffers from severe drought; crops fail to ripen. We fear that demonic calamities will arise in succession: pure yang ascends, congealed yin lingers below; the two qi fail to interact; the mysterious moisture does not descend. Scorching winds and blazing sun afflict the people; crops wither and parch; fish in dried ponds dread the daylight.

This arises because the Son of Heaven, having received the Mandate of Heaven, rules over all domains, yet the Three Talents, the lords and governors, the ministers and local officials have failed to govern with due care, and their administrative achievements fall short. We, Your servants, bear the heavy responsibility of the Dao yet lack the means to propagate its transformative power. Unable to rectify and harmonize the proper sequence of qi, we have caused the Five Phases to lose their balance, inviting the onslaught of celestial disasters.

We have searched the statutes and laws: the qi of the Dao is vast and all-covering, moistening and nourishing all living beings. We have learned that Qian knows the Great Beginning, and Kun brings things to completion. When Heaven and Earth interact in harmony, all things flourish. Spring gives birth, summer nurtures growth, autumn brings harvest, and winter stores away. When yin and yang are harmonious and compliant, grasses and trees flourish, and the Five Grains ripen. The Great Yin governs rain. On the day of *Lichun*, men sow the fields, and women tend to mulberry and hemp, hoping that by autumn and winter they may provide tribute and taxes, sustaining all life under Heaven and upon Earth.

In the second month of *Lichun*, the Five Grains begin to be sown. When rainwater is balanced and harmonious, the Five Grains thrive, and harmonious qi accumulates. Yet for some days now, scorching drought has persisted; sweet rain has not fallen. Yang qi waxes excessive; the sky lacks the impulse to send forth clouds; the earth lacks the moisture of vital fluids. We, Your servants, though unworthy, dare not presume, yet in accordance with the statutes and laws of the Heavenly Master, we venture through boiling waters and scorching fires to humbly submit this memorial. With utmost trepidation and fear, we kowtow, acknowledging our capital offense.

We beseech the Most High, the Boundless Great Dao, the Three Master Lords: You love life and abhor death. We implore You to bestow the transformative power of the Great Dao. May the officials in charge distinguish the Five Phases, regulate the pitch-pipes, array the Eight Trigrams, and mark the months and solar terms, so that yang does not encroach upon its bounds, yin does not retreat from its proper measure. When the Five comes to rest upon the One, Water naturally moistens below; when the Five ascends to the Two, Fire naturally flames upward; when the Five rides upon the Three, Wood naturally bends and straightens; when the Five removes the Four, Metal congeals and transforms; when the Five pairs with itself, the Law nourishes crops. Only when the Five are complete does nothing fail to grow. Then may the *Chunhuo* constellation withdraw its flames, the *Xuanxiao* constellation release its moisture, the *Jisu* constellation pour forth its tongue, the *Bisu* constellation stir its roots. May the coarse stones of the Five Marchmounts and the surging springs of the Four Marshes burst forth.

We humbly implore Your celestial mercy. We reverently request that from the Lingtai Palace, one Han Ming Lord and one hundred twenty officials and generals be dispatched to command the celestial thunder. From the Yuanming Palace, one Xiao Xuan Ming Lord and one hundred twenty officials and generals be dispatched to command Lord Lü, Son of the River Earl; the Thirty-Six Water Emperors; the Twelve Stream Maidens; the Nine River Water Emperors; the subordinate officials of the River Pacification Marquis; and the Water Deities of the Central Region, to summon clouds and send down rain. From the Hetian Palace, one Jiuhai Beixuan Lord and one hundred twenty officials and generals be dispatched to send forth water qi and release wind and thunder. From the Taishan Palace, the Nine Valley Lords of Sizhou and one hundred twenty officials and generals be dispatched to raise water qi. We further request the Nine Sea Lords and Water Emperors of Sizhou, the Envoys of Floating Clouds, and one hundred ten officials and generals to descend together. May they join with the illustrious Earth Lord of this prefecture, county, and township; the spirits of the famous mountains and great marshes, the source-valleys and rivers; the ancient and present ministers and great officials who have rendered service to the people and are enshrined in temples; and all the Perfected Officials of villages, townships, hamlets, and wards. May they register the qi, transmit the talismans, and govern the temple offices. May all the divine lords descend, unite their hearts and strength, assist the Dao of Heaven, perform their numinous powers, summon clouds and send down rain, bestowing abundant moisture and copious soaking. May the parched seedlings receive the glory of fattening moisture; may the myriad people gain the Mandate of renewal.

When the task is accomplished and the affair established, may their merits be reported and their ranks promoted. May the Lords of Wind and Rain likewise ascend to the Three Heavens to receive their due reward. We pray that the Celestial Bureau issue a decree to swiftly cause the drought demons to perish in accordance with this memorial. We specially beseech the Three Masters of the Most High to grant efficacy and verification, that we may not fail in our trust.

May the Most High, in Your discernment, have mercy upon our foolish inadequacy.

We respectfully entrust this to the Direct Envoys of the Two Officials, the Left and Right Official Envoys of the Orthodox Unity Merit Officers, the Scribes of Yin-Yang Divine Formulas, the Charioteers of the Red Talisman Statutes, and the Courier Horses of the Strong Winds, two officials each, to carry forth.

We, Your servants, humbly memorialize on behalf of the parched and desiccated qi of this realm, fearing the failure of the hundred grains. We kowtow and beseech the Celestial Officials to descend in due season, bestowing flowing moisture and abundant soaking.

One precious memorial is hereby submitted to the Three Celestial Bureaus, awaiting Your decree.

We, Your servants, with utmost trepidation and fear, kowtow and bow our heads in reverence, submitting this for Your attention.

**Petition of Gratitude and Atonement for One’s Destiny**

In accordance with the ritual rank, I declare: Born of the womb, a descendant of the lower officials’ lineage, I have been favored across a thousand generations to serve the Orthodox Unity, entering the gates of the Dao. By the grace of my teachers and elders, I have received honors, been granted talismans and registers for self-discipline, advanced to the Middle Vehicle, and borne the weight of their trust. Yet I, your servant, am dull-witted, my spirit and qi unsettled, my three *hun* souls unguarded, my seven *po* souls restless. In utmost reverence and fear, I bow my head and prostrate myself before the August Jade Emperor.

I and my seven generations of ancestors have committed hidden sins and manifest transgressions, accumulating the guilt of killing and harming living beings, all recorded by the Three Officials. From this day forward, I beseech that my ten thousand transgressions be dissolved, my sins erased, malevolent qi annihilated, and the nine blessings perpetually secure. May the souls of my seven generations of ancestors, down to my distant descendants, ascend and be reborn, returning to the womb as infants.

May I, your servant, attain the longevity of the immortals, eternal life in the Great Void, and bow to the Jade Purity of the North.

In utmost reverence and fear, I bow my head and prostrate myself before the Three Primordial Lords of the Great Simplicity.

I and my seven generations of ancestors, down to myself, have committed hidden sins and manifest transgressions, the guilt of killing living beings, all recorded before the Emperor. From this day forward, I beseech that my sins be erased, death struck from the records and life inscribed, my ten thousand transgressions dissolved. **Memorial of Accepting an Official Post**

With due rank and position, I respectfully state:
By examining the official records, I, [Name], as a lowly official, was born in ignorance yet fortunate to encounter this era of prosperity. Grateful for the heavens’ and earth’s benevolent light, I have been granted a place among the common folk.

In my former service under [Name]’s court, upon fulfilling my duties, I was promoted to the post of [Name]. The royal command having been issued, I dare not delay. On the appointed day when I received the seal and tablet, I bowed in reverence to the Dao’s pure and refined *qi*, and without regard for the times or rulers, I turned to my teacher’s Way and now submit this memorial to seek mercy.

I humbly present this petition to the throne, requesting:
One **Juzhuque Lord (朱雀君)**, with one hundred twenty officers, to oversee the **Luo Ping Palace (洛平宫)**, ensuring harmony among the people and joy among guests—so that all may feast with laughter and no grievance remains.

Further, I request:
One **Lord of Ranked Officials (位官受爵君)**, with one hundred twenty officers each,
And one **Lord of the Four Quarters’ Barbarians (四方夷蛮戎狄君)**, with one hundred twenty officers each—all to be summoned together to guard me.

After receiving the seal and tablet, may all malevolent *qi* of calamity and harm be dispelled, so that my career may flourish, my official tenure be prosperous, and my life secure and unburdened—thus fulfilling my pledge.

The officials I have requested shall be recorded by the **Central Palace (中宫)**, and I pray that no resentment may arise.

May the grace of the **Supreme Dao (太上)** be forever bestowed.

I humbly request one **Celestial Official of the Hour (辰)**.

In the **Edict of Governing Officials and Attending to the People (临官莅民章)**, I submit my petition with proper rank and protocol:

*"I, [Name], a man of low wisdom, have been mistakenly favored by Your Great Grace, selected by the times, and appointed as Magistrate of [Chu] County. Having received the royal command, I must now govern the people and affairs of the realm.

Yet, in these times of deceit and corruption, where human and ghostly forces vie for power, and mortal efforts are insufficient to avert calamities, I now, on the [specific] day of this month, set forth on my journey. I shall arrive at my post on the [specific] day of the [specific] month, relying solely on the **Dao-qi (道气)**. I dare not consult omens or inquire of auspicious times.

Upon entering my jurisdiction, I fear being harmed by the **land’s spirits and deities (土地精灵)**, the **ritual masters and ancestral shrines (符师社庙)**, lingering **qi of past feasts (饮食故气)**, the **General of the Year-Pillar (太岁将军)**, the **taboos along the Dao (道上禁诃)**, the **Five Phases’ Celestial Lords and their correspondences (五行王相)**, and the **forbidden omens of the *Kui* and *Gang* (魁纲诸忌)**. I therefore declare my arrival in advance and beseech protection.

With utmost reverence, I submit this petition, praying that the **Central Palace (上官)** may instruct the **local land deities (土地真官)**, the **postal couriers and relay stations (邮书驿骑)**, and the **watchtowers and villages (亭传里邑)** to clear the way and guard my person.

I further request:
One **Lord of Prosperity and Decline (昌落君)**, with one hundred twenty officers,
And one **General of Auspicious Protection (佑护将军)**, one **Lord of Ten Thousand Blessings (万福丈人)**, with their officers, to dispel all calamities.

One **Lord of Release and Exemption (解除禁害君)**, with one hundred twenty officers, along with the officials of the **Four Quarters’ Barbarians (四方夷蛮戎狄君)**, all assembled together below, to jointly guard my person, the **General of the Year-Pillar (太岁将军)**, the **Four Seasonal Celestial Depleters (四时王耗)**, and the **myriad prohibitions and omens (千禁万忌)**—so that my arrival and entry into office may be secure, my tenure free of strife, my speech unobstructed, my health serene, my career ascending, and my year’s end fulfilled with my wishes.

May the **times’ officials and officers** record my merits and report my labors.

May the grace of the **Supreme Dao (太上)** be forever bestowed."

I humbly petition for a single auspicious hour.

**Memorial for the Elimination of Obstructive Calamities**
*(Submitted in proper rank and form)*

I respectfully report: According to the official records, I have encountered this fateful juncture, granted the honor of serving in Qinghua, bearing the insignia of celestial officials, and receiving imperial favor in all my comings and goings. Truly, this fills me with profound gratitude and relief.

From my ancestral lineage to the present, my family has inherited official rank and titles, all through the sovereign’s boundless grace. Now, I am unworthy of holding this office, and on this day, I reverently accept the royal command, relying entirely upon the Great Dao. Without divination or inquiry, without selecting a propitious day or hour, I proceed with a sincere heart.

Since assuming this post, I have been plagued by unsettling dreams and waking visions, alternating with recurring illnesses and strange, inexplicable phenomena—unclear in their origin. Upon consulting the annual almanac and the celestial cycles of the Six Jia, I find that on the day I received my commission, my natal branch was Five Li, while my current year-branch was Jiawu, clashing with Zi. Moreover, I accepted the commission in the eleventh month—a month of decline. The Year-Pillar is [omitted], with [omitted] as the official killer and [omitted] as the grave killer, and I myself am the official killer, all converging in mutual assault.

The day’s influence descends upon the Six Harmonies, further compounded by the Six Calamities. I have heard that...

「The Dao/Way knows no prohibitions or taboos; without sincerity and devotion, it cannot be attained. To avert calamities and repel misfortunes, they have come to inform me, seeking official documents. I humbly submit this request, hoping that the Way’s *qi* may flow downward.

I respectfully petition the Heavenly Hall Lord, requesting a hundred and twenty officials, to govern the An Yang Palace, overseeing the removal of the Nine Heavenly Prohibitions. The one receiving the commission shall eliminate [them]. I further request the Heavenly King and his Thousand Two Hundred Immortal Maidens, clad in green robes, to collect the ten thousand people of the world, bestowing upon them titles and seals of gold and silver, granting them divine understanding, averting calamities and repelling misfortunes, and ensuring their lives span a hundred years. If, on the day I receive my appointment, the time should be Five Li, any malevolent spirits and myriad harms shall all be eliminated. I beg the High Official to dispatch the requested personnel accordingly.

Within my jurisdiction, there are so many officials—two hundred and forty in total. If it be a prefecture, there are twenty-four officials. If a commandery, eighteen officials. If a county, seven officials. All united in strength, they shall help me avert and repel evil, eliminate prohibitions, and ensure no other matters arise in office. Discussions and judgments shall be in harmony with virtue, officials and commoners alike shall rejoice, and thus I may be promoted in time, ending the year in stability.

On the day my wishes are fulfilled, the petitioned Heavenly Officials shall speak of my merits and labor, not betraying their trust in me. The favor is bestowed by the Supreme Sovereign.

I beg for mercy. Request for Promotion to High Office

With proper rank, I submit: In accordance with the official documents, I have always been one born from the womb of flesh, with descendants of mere bones. Formerly, through the *Lèhuà* ritual, I was entrusted with the Way to preserve and govern myself. The grace bestowed upon me has been profound and generous, filling me with joy and comfort.

Descended from a noble lineage, my family has long held officialdom as its profession. I have accumulated ranks as various officials, managing royal affairs with distinction, my name and reputation both flourishing. Now I return to this post, which is not something a mere mortal can achieve. I am deeply moved by the Way’s vast protection and care.

My current office holds the critical affairs of state, or perhaps lies beyond the frontiers, as the case may be. My duties encompass the grand governance of all under Heaven, where both officials and ministers are powerful, and the commoners, accustomed to their privileges, are all too familiar with deceit. There are many lawsuits, and justice is hard to discern. I fear that if my words or actions falter, I may incur blame and censure, and thus I humbly rely on the Way’s broad acceptance and supplication, seeking these officials to safeguard and protect me.

Though unworthy, I bear great responsibility and cannot bear the burden of the mortals’ petitions. I dare to violate the solemnity of the court, humbly presenting this memorial, and hope for Your compassionate grace and protection.

I earnestly request the Twelve Lords of the Nine Barbarians, Eight Man, Six Rong, and Five Di—each twelve in number—along with their officials, soldiers, and attendants, to encircle my residence, standing guard at my sides.

I further petition the Five Lords of Ten Thousand Blessings, each with a hundred and twenty officials, to dispel lingering malevolent *qi* and vengeful spirits, to curse those who seek to harm me, and to repel death and bring life, to repel misfortune and bring blessings.

I further petition the Five Lords of Great Stars, each with a hundred and twenty officials, to govern the Stone Immortal Palace, and to suppress the slanderous tongues of the commoners, so that false accusations cannot take root, and to restore them to their proper places, ensuring that commoners and officials alike meet with smiles and joy.

I further petition the Lords of Auxiliary Generals and Ten Thousand Blessings, each with a hundred and twenty officials, to guard my person.

I further petition the Lord of Azure Darkness, with a hundred and twenty officials, to govern the Great Gate Palace, suppressing the resentment, complaints, and malevolent *qi* of the office, preventing them from reaching me.

I hope that when the Heavenly Officials arrive, their single attendant shall gather with the officials and commoners of my state, commandery, county, village, and hamlet, each following their respective lord, to surround and protect my person. They shall dispel evil spirits, pestilence, and epidemic *qi*, and any schemes of enticement and harm shall all be eliminated, allowing my heart to open and my mind to clear. I shall comprehend the wisdom of the Five Spirits, fully understand what is spoken, and act accordingly. My words shall be as trustworthy as those of a thousand mouths, my intentions as sincere as the deepest vows. My household shall be ever peaceful, and by year’s end, I shall achieve prosperity, benefiting both the public and private spheres, as proof of my devotion.

On that day, I shall speak of the merits of the Heavenly Officials, requesting their promotion, to repay their labor and suffering. I beg for forgiveness of all my great and small faults, my myriad sins. The favor is bestowed by the Supreme Sovereign.

I further beg for mercy.」

The Most High and All-Venerable Celestial Worthies, distinguished by their ranks:

The **Steward of Martial Campaigns** presents his humble petition. In strict accordance with the official records, I, [Name], by birth a mortal of flesh and blood, a descendant of lowly officials, through the fortune of fate and the grace of the Great Transformation, have received the benevolent coverage of Heaven’s favor, truly filling me with joy and gratitude.

Yet, due to my own stubborn ignorance and accumulated sins—mountains high—disasters and calamities have continually befallen me.

Now, the journey is long and arduous, traversing rivers and mountains, passing through Huai and Si, advancing toward the enemy’s strongholds. In the midst of white blades and poisoned steel, the clash of arms is fierce, and both civil and martial authorities press down upon me. The military laws are severe, execution swift, and those who wield power cruelly oppress others, forcing them into violence. My merits are meager, and I cannot avert misfortune.

Fearful that I may perish in this dire strait without escape, I rely upon the **Dao-qi** of the myriad people, humbly presenting this memorial to the **Treaty-Officer**, beseeching protection.

With deepest reverence, I prostrate myself and submit this petition, appealing to the **Nine Lords of the Eastern Barbarians**, the **Eight Lords of the Southern Snares**, the **Six Lords of the Western Steppe**, and the **Five Lords of the Northern Di**, twelve each in number. I further implore the **Thousand-Li Lord**, the **Ten-Thousand-Li General**, and the **General of Auspicious Protection**, that they may jointly guard and shield me, following and covering me wherever I may be, ensuring my constant safety.

May they repel all calamities—epidemics, malevolent spirits, and bandits—that I may escape the blades of war, transcend this peril, and find favor within the ranks, free from blame or censure, as proof of my sincerity.

I shall then speak of my merits before the **Temporal Lords and officials**, repaying their labor and toil.

The grace is granted by the Most High and All-Venerable Celestial Worthies.

I further beg for mercy.

**Chapter of the Vermilion Pine Child**, Volume Six, concludes.

chunks.original_text: 赤松子章历 经名：赤松子章历。 撰人不详，据考应为唐代道士编集。 系早期天师道上章仪范。 六卷。 底本出处：《正统道藏》洞玄部表奏类。 赤松子章历卷之一 谨按《太真科》及《赤松子历》，汉代人鬼交杂，精邪遍行，太上垂慈，下降鹤呜山，授张天师正一盟威符箓一百二十阶，及千二百官仪，三百大章，法文秘要，救治人物。 天师遂迁二十四治，敷行正一章符，领户化民，广行阴德。 尔后年代绵远，宝章缺失，今之所存，十得一二。 又按：赤松子问天老平长：己丑上章，何不报？ 平长答云：见扶章赍到天门，门闭。 复问：一日一夜何时开，何时闭？ 平长具答，悉如科文。 且世人求贡章奏，或为家国，或为己身，或为眷属，或为先亡，种种不同，具如分别。 又云：人生年命，悉有星宿管系。 若为恶事，记名黑簿，令人精神恍惚，梦寐不安，既多迍邅，更减年算。 若清心信向之士，崇尚道法，求乞章符，奏即罪灭福生，增添禄寿，先灵迁达，愿念从心。 凡曰奏章，先须备信，神明鉴烛，冀质诚心。 若都无信，即神明不纳，责子有悭鄙不舍之心。 又云：章无的信，富饶者增之，贫穷者减之。 或有官高富足之家，心希功德，而吝惜财物，便效贫穷之人，出信如此，亦无益於有为。 科云：有寒栖贫乏之人，求请章醮，师为代出法信。 旧章虽各具所用，大抵有三：天子、王公、庶人。 且尊卑不同，品目各异，不可般混而无分别。 科云：章信之物，施散贫穷，宜行阴德，不可师全用之。 十分为计，师可费入者三分而已。 天科严峻，犯者获罪於三官，殃延九祖，永为下鬼，可不慎之！ 今并次比，具有条贯，冀行之者，知次第焉。 章信 天旱章

**The Red Pine Master’s Petition Rituals**

*Scripture Title:* *The Red Pine Master’s Petition Rituals*. Author unknown; according to scholarly consensus, compiled by Tang-dynasty Daoist priests. A manual of early Celestial Master Daoist petition rituals. Six juan in total. Base text from the *Zhengtong Daoist Canon*, *Dongxuan* section, *Petition Memorials* category.

**The Red Pine Master’s Petition Rituals, Juan One**

Respectfully following *The Supreme Perfection Regulations* and *The Red Pine Master’s Records*: In the Han dynasty, humans and spirits intermingled, and malevolent forces spread unchecked. The Most High, moved by compassion, descended upon Mount Heming and bestowed upon Heavenly Master Zhang the *Orthodox Unity Alliance Registers* of one hundred twenty ranks, along with one thousand two hundred official protocols, three hundred major petitions, and esoteric ritual texts—all to succor and heal the living.

The Heavenly Master then established twenty-four dioceses, disseminating the *Orthodox Unity* petitions and talismans, registering households, and transforming the people while widely practicing hidden virtue. Yet as the ages passed, the precious petitions were lost, and what remains today is but one or two parts in ten.

Further, according to the record: Red Pine Master asked Heavenly Elder Pingchang, “Why has the petition submitted on the *jichou* day gone unreported?” Pingchang replied, “I saw the petition-bearer arrive at the Heavenly Gate, but the gate was closed.” The Master asked again, “When does it open and close in the span of a day and night?” Pingchang answered in full, precisely as the ritual codes prescribe.

Moreover, when people submit petitions, their purposes vary—some for the state and household, others for themselves, their kin, or deceased ancestors. Each case differs and must be distinguished accordingly.

It is also said: The lifespan and fate of every person are governed by stellar constellations. If one commits evil deeds, their name is recorded in the Black Register, causing their spirit to grow restless, their dreams troubled, their path beset by misfortune, and their years diminished. But for those of pure heart who revere the Dao and its methods, seeking petitions and talismans, their transgressions are erased, blessings arise, their emoluments and longevity increase, their ancestors ascend, and their wishes are fulfilled.

All petitions must first be accompanied by offerings, so that the divine luminaries may witness one’s sincerity. Without offerings, the gods will not accept them, and one will be rebuked for stinginess and reluctance to give.

It is further said: The offerings for petitions are not fixed—those of wealth may increase them, while the poor may reduce them. Yet even among high officials and affluent households, if they covet merit but begrudge their wealth, mimicking the poor in their offerings, such conduct will yield no benefit.

The codes state: For those who are destitute and impoverished, seeking petitions and jiao rituals, the master may provide the ritual offerings on their behalf.

Though old petitions vary in purpose, they generally fall into three categories: those for the Son of Heaven, for nobles and high officials, and for commoners. Since ranks differ, their forms must not be conflated without distinction.

The codes also state: Offerings for petitions should be distributed to the poor to cultivate hidden virtue; the master must not use them entirely for himself. Calculating by tenths, the master may only take three parts for his own use. The celestial statutes are severe—those who violate them incur punishment from the Three Officials, their misfortune extending to nine generations, condemning them to eternal servitude as lowly spirits. How could one not be cautious!

Now, these matters are arranged and compared, with clear principles established, so that practitioners may know the proper order.

**Three Grades of Petitions**
One thousand two hundred official rituals, three hundred major petitions. Though each petition includes its own offerings, the teachings have been transmitted for a long time, and practitioners often make additions or omissions. Thus, ranks become indistinguishable, and distinctions unclear. Here, three grades are extracted as a standard.

**Silk and Colors:**
The Son of Heaven uses purple silk in *pi* and *shu* quantities; princes and dukes use their life-color silk in *zhang* quantities; commoners use plain silk in *chi* quantities.

**Ritual Coins:**
The Son of Heaven uses gold coins; princes and dukes use silver coins; commoners use copper coins.

**Rice Offerings:**
The Son of Heaven offers three *shi* and six *dou*; princes and dukes offer two *shi* and four *dou*; commoners offer one *shi* and two *dou*.

**Ritual Oil:**
The Son of Heaven offers one *shi* and two *dou*; princes and dukes offer six *dou* and four *sheng*; commoners offer two *dou* and two *sheng*.

**Incense:**
The Son of Heaven offers a full *jin*; princes and dukes offer half a *jin*; commoners offer three or five *liang*.

**Paper, Brushes, Ink, and Cinnabar:**
These are provided for the officiant to draft petitions, correct errors, and revise drafts. All petitions must include them; none may be omitted. Other items follow their original categories and quantities. Violations will result in a reduction of lifespan.

**Petition Texts**
When submitting a petition, first prepare a written statement listing one’s native place, village name, official title, full name, age, household members, living dependents, and the number of males and females, young and old. According to Daoist regulations, present the ritual offerings at a designated place to a designated master, requesting the submission of the petition. Humbly beseech compassion and special intervention. The statement should convey the matter plainly, without ornamentation—unrefined yet not crude, simple yet not ostentatious, truthful yet not deceitful, direct yet not unrestrained, articulate yet not verbose, modest yet not vulgar, pure yet not turbid. If sincerity is concise and earnest, it will move Heaven and Earth, stir spirits and gods, ascend to the celestial bureaus, and bring swift retribution. **First and Second Months**

*Zi* day: execution of son; *chou* day: great inauspiciousness; *yin-mao* day: inauspicious; *chen* day: fiftyfold; *si* day: execution of son; *wu* day: self-punishment; *wei* day: execution of wife; *shen* day: execution of father; *you* day: fiftyfold; *xu* day: twentyfold; *hai* day: inauspicious.

**Ninth and Tenth Months**

**Eleventh and Twelfth Months**

**Method for Writing Talismans**
When intending to write a talisman, first face the *wang* direction, knock the teeth, command the sword-water, visualize the Seven Stars, recite the incantation, and spray the water. Then declare:

*"Primordial Life True Person, Generals Tang, Ge, and Zhou, there is now a man or woman named so-and-so suffering from illness, who petitions me for aid and protection. I reverently follow the Daoist method, bestowing upon so-and-so this true talisman of the Dao to swallow or wear. May the true officials, direct talisman messengers, and the hundred thousand myriad layers of Dao qi descend into this talisman by command. Let the spirits mobilize the qi, search out and expel evil spirits, execute demonic thieves, and deliver salvation to the celestial and human realms."*

Next, visualize the five-colored true qi before the altar. Above the true qi, to the left and right, stand the Direct Talisman Lads, clad in vermilion robes and azure skirts. Before the altar stands a Talisman General in vermilion robes and a dark crown, girded with a sword and holding a battle-axe. To his left and right stand two Direct Talisman Attendants, wearing yellow caps, yellow skirts, and crimson-brown garments, each holding a sword. Before me are the sun on the left and the moon on the right, nine inches from my face, their radiance covering a vermilion vessel. Above my head are the Seven Stars, the stars upon my head, and the *piao* upon the vermilion vessel.

Once this is complete, recite thrice: *"Conjoined Brightness of the Heavenly Thearch and the Sun."*

Then, visualize the vermilion brush as a *tengshe*, hold the breath, and write the talisman.

**General Method for Writing Talismans**
First, outline the four sides of the talisman with azure ink, then write the talisman text within in cinnabar. If azure ink is unavailable, cinnabar may also be used.

When writing talismans to cure illnesses caused by evil, use true cinnabar mixed with tiger bone. Once ground, dip the brush and write the talisman while reciting the incantation:

*"I solemnly command the true officials within my five bodily constituents: my hun-soul is the Heavenly Father, my po-soul is the Earthly Mother, my head is Lord Thunder, my hair is black clouds, my crown is the Bright Star, my forehead is the Vermilion Bird, my eyebrows are the Qilin, my eyes are the sun and moon, my nose is the Mighty Tiger, my upper lip is the Earl of Wind, my lower lip is the Master of Rain, my tongue is the Governor of the Nine Provinces, my throat is the Nine-Layered Tower, my left cheek is the Eastern Kingly Lord, my right cheek is the Queen Mother of the West, my ears are the Immortal Lads of Distant Hearing, my neck is the Heavenly Pillar, my shoulders are the Vajras, my elbows are the Mighty Warriors, my left arm is the Great General Xuanji of Expelling Barbarians, my right arm is the Great General Yuheng of Breaking Barbarians, my palms are fire chariots, my fingers are armored soldiers, my liver is the Green Thearch, my lungs are the White Thearch, my heart is the Red Thearch, my kidneys are the Black Thearch, my spleen is the Yellow Thearch, my intestines are the Yellow Dragon, my gallbladder is the Great One, my bladder is the River Earl, my blood is the Water Official, my sinews are the Heavenly Net, my bones are the Earthly Net, my hair is the Heavenly Snare, my feet are the White Horse, my forward steps are the Three Officials, each leading seventy million troops. Mounting great chariots, they emerge from within my body to assist me in writing the talisman and mobilizing the qi, destroying and executing malevolent demons, *wangliang*, *chimei*, evil ghosts, and perverse qi. Swiftly, swiftly, in accordance with the oral command of the Most High!"*

chunks.original_text: 甲申旬治病使者，治病功曹，申时太上还治。 甲午旬治病使者，正一功曹，日中太上还治。 甲辰旬治病使者，中部功曹，食时太上还治。 甲寅旬治病使者，直使功曹，平明太上还治。 右凡书符，取此时乞愿，符禁迅速。 书章法 书章，笔、砚勿杂用。 研墨，左转四十九重，磨亦然。 以闻，去再拜下一寸。 臣姓，去以闻隔三行。 太清，去臣姓三行。 太岁，去太清三行。 若书章已成，而有小事，经年不可上。 若未下细字，经月可上。 细字，上度三寸五分，中度四寸五分，下度五寸，不得过此。 今人多言一寸五分，非也。 章至太岁，纸尽，不可上。 若有主行，即可。 若两行，可全纸续之。 错误脱字，小章不过三字，大章以意量之。 书章，上让八分，下通蚁走。 书章，以巾敷案上，不得令着床，勿以衣着章上，及落地。 书章，入静，不得常人乱闹，论及他事，臭秽之言。 书章，不得以笔点水中及口，当闭口，不得有所食，及气冲。 书章，净洗手，向北书。 身经殗秽，不得书章。 书不得败字不成，纸不得破裂，不得饮酒、食肉，熏秽，当整理衣冠，不得裸露。 书章，当须匍匐恭敬，不得蹲踞。 书章毕，先校读一遍，然后奏之。 臣字不得上行头，不得悬生露死。 鬼字不得居行首。 不得抽破人姓名，不得令人窃读，触动太清。 日月不得预下，当在临时。 若急事上章，当用朱笔题署。 若上逐鬼章，当朱书所上正一弟子姓名。 若治邪病章，用青纸。 三官君吏，贵在青色。 若疰气鬼病作击鬼章，朱书青纸。 章奏了，於治中烧，和真朱二分捣，和蜜为丸，平旦入靖，再拜服之，垂死皆活。 莫令人知。 若因病入靖书章，即四面烧香火。 三元日 正月十五日上元

For the *jiashen*旬, the Illness-Curing Messenger commands the Illness-Curing Merit Clerk; at the *shen* hour, the Most High returns to govern.
For the *jiawu*旬, the Illness-Curing Messenger commands the Orthodox Unity Merit Clerk; at midday, the Most High returns to govern.
For the *jiachen*旬, the Illness-Curing Messenger commands the Central Department Merit Clerk; at the breakfast hour, the Most High returns to govern.
For the *jiayin*旬, the Illness-Curing Messenger commands the Direct Attendant Merit Clerk; at dawn, the Most High returns to govern.

Whenever writing talismans, make your petition at these times for swift efficacy in talismanic restraint.

**Method for Writing Memorials**
When writing memorials, do not mix brushes and inkstones. Grind the ink by rotating the inkstick leftward forty-nine times; the grinding stone should be treated likewise. The heading "With respectful hearing" should be placed one inch below the first bow. The supplicant’s surname should be placed three lines below "With respectful hearing." "Great Clarity" should be placed three lines below the supplicant’s surname. "Great Year" should be placed three lines below "Great Clarity."

If a memorial is completed but contains minor matters, it may not be submitted for a year. If small characters have not yet been added, it may be submitted within a month. For small characters: the upper measure is three inches and five *fen*, the middle measure four inches and five *fen*, and the lower measure five inches—no more than this. Many today speak of one inch and five *fen*, which is incorrect. When the memorial reaches "Great Year," if the paper is exhausted, it may not be submitted. If there is a presiding officer to deliver it, then it may. If two lines remain, the paper may be fully extended to continue.

For errors or omitted characters: small memorials should not exceed three characters; large memorials should be judged by context. When writing memorials, leave eight *fen* of space at the top and allow the bottom to extend to the edge of the paper. Place a cloth on the desk when writing memorials; do not let them touch the bed. Do not place clothing on the memorial or let it fall to the ground.

When writing memorials, enter a state of stillness. Do not allow ordinary people to cause disturbance, nor discuss other matters or speak of foul or defiling things. When writing memorials, do not dip the brush in water or in the mouth. Keep the mouth closed, do not eat anything, and avoid exhaling forcefully. Wash hands clean and face north when writing. If the body has been defiled, do not write memorials. Do not write incomplete or flawed characters, nor use torn or damaged paper. Do not drink alcohol, eat meat, or expose oneself to foul odors. Dress in proper attire; do not expose the body.

When writing memorials, one must prostrate oneself in reverence; do not squat or sit casually. After completing a memorial, first proofread it once before submitting it. The character "Your servant" (*chen*) must not appear at the beginning of a line, nor should it be placed where the living and dead are juxtaposed. The character for "ghost" must not occupy the start of a line. Do not tear out or damage a person’s name, nor allow others to secretly read it, lest it disturb the Great Clarity. The characters for "sun" and "moon" should not be written in advance; they should be added at the time of submission.

If submitting an urgent memorial, use a vermilion brush for the heading. When submitting a memorial to expel ghosts, write in vermilion the name of the Orthodox Unity disciple submitting it. For memorials to cure illnesses caused by malevolent spirits, use blue paper. The Lords and Officers of the Three Officials hold blue in high esteem. For memorials to strike down ghostly illnesses caused by *zhu* qi, write in vermilion on blue paper.

After the memorial is submitted, burn it in the place of treatment. Grind two parts of true cinnabar and mix with honey to form pills. At dawn, enter the oratory, bow twice, and consume them—even those at death’s door will revive. Let no one know of this.

If writing a memorial due to illness while in the oratory, burn incense on all four sides.

**Three Primordial Days**
The fifteenth day of the first month is the Upper Primordial.

chunks.original_text: 七月十五日中元 十月十五日下元． 右件，天地水三官检校之日，可修斋祈福。 三会日 正月五日上会 七月七日中会 十月五日下会 右此日宜上章言功，不避疾风暴雨，日月昏晦，天地禁闭。 其日，天帝一切大圣俱下，同会治堂，分形布影，万里之外，响应齐同。 此日上章，受度法箓，男女行德施功，消灾散祸，悉不禁制。 又女青鬼律一写．天会丙午，地会壬午，人会壬子，日会庚午，月会庚申，星辰会辛酉，五行会甲辰，四时会甲戌，天节甲午，地节甲申，人节甲子。 右已上日，可立功德，乞福大吉。 子时相破 子时破午，午时破子，凡启醮，宜用子午二时。 若值相破，及斗击在子，须避子。 在午须避午。 若急疾亦得或避，得为佳。 奏章向背 日中奏章向东，夜奏向北。 又云：白日受度向东，破契子午、请命星宿、急疾章，皆向北，存大帝。 自非星宿大章，登坛大事，并收捕驱除急章，不烦露上。 治病向鬼门，消灾厄向地户，求长生向天门，求富贵财利向地户，消口舌咒诅向人门，厌虎向寅地，厌蛇向巳地。 又曰：作福延年、消灾厌病，宜东向。 解墓阴责，开心聪明，过度灾厄，宜西向。 疾病垂死，章符治救，宜北向。 治身养命，求乞富贵，宜南向。 上章谢罪，宜北向。 正月、五月、七月、九月治病，不向东。 四月、八月、十二月治病，不向南。 七月、三月、十月治病，勿向西。 二月、六月、十月治病，勿向北。 右已上向背，章符治病，不得越错。 如违，依科夺算。 逐月诣宫 正月、十二月上诣太上虚无丈人宫，二月上诣太上玄老仙都宫，三月、四月上诣太上三天太清宫，五月上诣太上重道宫，六月、七月上诣太上九黑文昌官，八月上诣太上天帝宫，九月、十月上诣太上大道宫，十一月上诣太上侍中左右监神诸将军宫，闰月随月宫上诣太上金单太岁宫。 或随前月。 逐日诣曹
